articles.headline: Guardrail Maker Trinity Industries Liable for Fraud in Texas
articles.snippet: A Texas jury awarded $175 million, an amount that could be tripled, in a case against Trinity Industries, which made systems that can malfunction during crashes and wreck cars.
articles.abstract: A Texas jury awarded $175 million, an amount that could be tripled, in a case against Trinity Industries, which made systems that can malfunction during crashes and wreck cars.
articles.lead_paragraph: Trinity Industries, the highway guardrail maker accused of selling systems that can malfunction during crashes and slice through cars, was found by a jury on Monday to have defrauded the federal government.
articles.byline: By Danielle Ivory and Aaron M. Kessler

articles.headline: Shipwreck Was Simple Murder, Migrants Recall
articles.snippet: Four days had passed since their overcrowded migrant boat had capsized in the Mediterranean, after being rammed in an apparent quarrel between smugglers. The Palestinians were now weak and hallucinating.
articles.abstract: Four days had passed since their overcrowded migrant boat had capsized in the Mediterranean, after being rammed in an apparent quarrel between smugglers. The Palestinians were now weak and hallucinating.
articles.lead_paragraph: VALLETTA, Malta — On the last morning, only four of the survivors remained. Two sets of Palestinian brothers, exhausted and adrift in the Mediterranean beneath a blazing white sun. The Awadallah brothers were delirious. Mohammed saw vampires rising from the waves. Ibrahim kept removing his life jacket, imagining himself at home in Gaza, changing his clothes.

articles.headline: With Farms Fading and Urban Might Rising, Power Shifts in Iowa
articles.snippet: A way of life is eroding as small towns hemorrhage younger residents, a potent but unpredictable undercurrent in a closely fought Senate race.
articles.abstract: A way of life is eroding as small towns hemorrhage younger residents, a potent but unpredictable undercurrent in a closely fought Senate race.
articles.lead_paragraph: LAURENS, Iowa — Pocahontas is running out of students. Public school enrollment in this corn-blanketed county in northern Iowa has plummeted 32 percent over the past decade as the population steadily shrinks. Schools have merged, classes have combined, and sports teams have consolidated, wiping out generations of tradition and rivalry.

articles.headline: The Truth Hidden by IBM’s Buybacks
articles.snippet: IBM’s chief executive has talked a good game. But all these maneuvers have been masking a truth: IBM’s success in recent years has been tied more to financial engineering than actual performance.
articles.abstract: IBM’s chief executive has talked a good game. But all these maneuvers have been masking a truth: IBM’s success in recent years has been tied more to financial engineering than actual performance.
articles.lead_paragraph: For many years, the International Business Machines Corporation’s earnings glided smoothly upward. Every quarter, IBM would report higher earnings per share. Even Warren Buffett invested in the company, disregarding his long-held aversion to technology companies as too challenging to forecast.

articles.headline: As Apple Pay Arrives, Witnessing the Next Step in Money. Maybe.
articles.snippet: Commerce experts say they think the involvement of Apple could be the impetus that moves mainstream consumers to digital payments.
articles.abstract: Commerce experts say they think the involvement of Apple could be the impetus that moves mainstream consumers to digital payments.
articles.lead_paragraph: David Donohue has a tough relationship with his wallet and the items inside it.

articles.headline: It Looked Like a Stabbing, but Takata Airbag Was the Killer
articles.snippet: An airbag appeared to explode and send shrapnel into a woman’s neck this month. Airbags made by Takata have been associated with at least three deaths and 14 million recalls.
articles.abstract: An airbag appeared to explode and send shrapnel into a woman’s neck this month. Airbags made by Takata have been associated with at least three deaths and 14 million recalls.
articles.lead_paragraph: ORLANDO, Fla. — Hien Tran lay dying in intensive care this month after a car accident, as detectives searched for clues about the apparent stab wounds in her neck.
articles.byline: By Hiroko Tabuchi and Christopher Jensen

articles.headline: Mixed Economic Signals From China
articles.snippet: A slowing in the pace of growth, partly by design, has made assessing the Chinese economy and predicting its prospects difficult.
articles.abstract: A slowing in the pace of growth, partly by design, has made assessing the Chinese economy and predicting its prospects difficult.
articles.lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Markets around the world have been jolted by fears that slowing growth and deflationary pressures in Europe, Japan and other major economies could derail the United States. But the health of China, for decades an engine of growth, has emerged as one of the most significant wild cards in the global economy.

articles.headline: Hoverboard? Still in the Future
articles.snippet: For the last 25 years, inventors like garage tinkerers, physics professors and engineers have been trying to make a hovering skateboard.
articles.abstract: For the last 25 years, inventors like garage tinkerers, physics professors and engineers have been trying to make a hovering skateboard.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS GATOS, Calif. — A lot of things can hover. There are helicopters. There are hovercraft. But for the last three decades, a generation of engineers and movie fans have been waiting for something else: a hovering skateboard like the one in “Back to the Future Part II.”

articles.headline: On TV, Hong Kong Openly Debates Democracy
articles.snippet: After more than three weeks of protests, the meeting resembled less a negotiating session than a high school debate.
articles.abstract: After more than three weeks of protests, the meeting resembled less a negotiating session than a high school debate.
articles.lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — After weeks of protests that have shaken this financial hub of 7.2 million people, residents thought they had seen it all. Then, on Tuesday night, something even more extraordinary happened, on live television: a polite debate between earnest students wearing black “Freedom Now” T-shirts and top Hong Kong leaders over the future of democracy.
articles.byline: By Michael Forsythe and Alan Wong
